Cards functionality¶

Card’s models¶

class cards.models.EnglishCards(id, english_word, russian_word, word_usage, img)¶

Bases: Model

exception DoesNotExist¶

Bases: ObjectDoesNotExist

exception MultipleObjectsReturned¶

Bases: MultipleObjectsReturned

save(*args, **kwargs)¶

The save function is a built-in function that saves the image to the database. The super() function allows us to access methods from parent class, in this case, the save method of the Model class. The img variable opens up our image file and stores it as an Image object. We then check if either height or width of our image is greater than 50 pixels (our desired size). If so, we create a new_img tuple with 50 as both values and use it to resize our original img object using thumbnail(). Finally, we save this resized version back into its original path.

Parameters:

  • self – Refer to the object itself.

  • args – Send a non-keyworded variable length argument list to the function

  • kwargs – Pass keyworded, variable-length argument list to a function

Returns:

The instance of the model

save(*args, **kwargs)¶

The save function is a built-in function that saves the image to the database. The super() function allows us to access methods from parent class, in this case, the save method of the Model class. The img variable opens up our image file and stores it as an Image object. We then check if either height or width of our image is greater than 50 pixels (our desired size). If so, we create a new_img tuple with 50 as both values and use it to resize our original img object using thumbnail(). Finally, we save this resized version back into its original path.

Parameters:

  • self – Refer to the current instance of the class

  • args – Send a non-keyworded variable length argument list to the function

  • kwargs – Pass keyworded, variable-length argument list to a function

Card’s views¶

class cards.views.card_views.CardsListView(**kwargs)¶

Return all cards when you open collection.

get_context_data(*_, object_list=None, **kwargs)¶

The get_context_data function is a function that allows you to pass additional context variables to the template. The get_context_data function takes in an optional object_list parameter, which is used by ListViews and DetailViews. It also takes in any number of keyword arguments (kwargs). The **kwargs are passed into the superclass’s get_context_data method, which returns a dictionary containing all of the context variables for this view.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • _ – Pass a list of arguments to the function

  • object_list – Pass the list of objects to the template

  • kwargs – Pass keyworded, variable-length argument list

Returns:

A dictionary of data that will be used to render the template

get_queryset()¶

The get_queryset function is used to filter the queryset of cards that are returned by the view. In this case, we want to return all cards in a collection. The collection_id is passed as an argument to the view and then used here to get all cards in that particular collection.

Parameters:

self – Represent the instance of the class

Returns:

A list of cards that belong to a certain collection

model¶

alias of CardsCollections

paginate_by = 1¶
template_name = 'cards/open_collection.html'¶
class cards.views.card_views.CreateCardView(**kwargs)¶
get(request)¶

The get function is used to render the form for a new card. It takes in a request object and returns an HTML page with the form.

Parameters:

  • self – Refer to the class itself

  • request – Get the user id

Returns:

The form object

post(request)¶

The post function is used to create a new card. It takes in the request and returns a rendered template with either an error message or success message. If the form is valid, it saves the form but does not commit it yet, then calls get_new_card from CardsServices which creates a new card object and adds it to the database. The function then renders either an error or success message depending on whether there was an issue creating the card.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the object itself

  • request – Get the information from the form

Returns:

A render function

template_name = 'cards/create_card.html'¶
class cards.views.card_views.CardDeleteView(**kwargs)¶
post(request, card_id, collection_id)¶

The post function is used to remove a card from the collection. It takes in the request, card_id and collection_id as parameters. The function then gets the collection by its id and gets the card from that specific collection. Then it removes that specific card from that specific collections cards list using .remove().

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • request – Pass the request object to the view

  • card_id – Get the card from the collection

  • collection_id – Get the collection object from the database

Returns:

A render of the collection page with a new queryset

template_name = 'cards/edit_collection.html'¶
class cards.views.collection_views.CollectionListView(**kwargs)¶
get_queryset()¶

The get_queryset function is used to filter the queryset of objects that will be displayed in the view. In this case, we are filtering by owner (the user who created it). This means that only cards collections created by a specific user will be shown.

Parameters:

self – Represent the instance of the class

Returns:

A list of objects that match the given query parameters

get(request)¶

The get function is used to render the form on the page. It takes in a request and returns a rendered template with context.

Parameters:

  • request – Pass the request object to the view

post(request)¶

The post function is used to create a new collection. It takes the request and form as parameters, validates the form, saves it if it’s valid and returns a message with success or error.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • request – Get the data from the form

Returns:

A render function that renders the template message_template

template_name = 'cards/create_collection.html'¶
class cards.views.collection_views.CollectionDeleteView(**kwargs)¶
get(request, collection_id)¶

The get function is used to retrieve a collection from the database. It takes in a request and an id of the collection that you want to retrieve. The function then uses CollectionServices to get the collection by its id, and returns it as context for rendering.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the object itself

  • request – Get the request object

  • collection_id – Get the collection from the database

Returns:

A render function

post(request, collection_id)¶

The post function is used to delete a collection. It takes in the request and collection_id as parameters. The function then gets the collection by its id, deletes it, and redirects to study cards.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the object itself

  • request – Pass the request object to the view

  • collection_id – Get the collection object from the database

Returns:

A redirect to the study_cards view

template_name = 'cards/deleting_warning.html'¶
class cards.views.collection_views.CollectionEditView(**kwargs)¶
get(request, collection_id)¶

The get function is used to render the editor page for a specific collection. It takes in a request and collection_id, then uses the CollectionServices class to get that specific collection. The function then renders the template with context containing: the queryset of cards belonging to that collection, the id of that particular card, and the name of the template being rendered.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • request – Get the request object

  • collection_id – Get the collection from the database

Returns:

A render function

template_name = 'cards/edit_collection.html'¶
class cards.views.collection_views.CollectionRenameView(**kwargs)¶
post(request, collection_id)¶

The post function is used to change the name of a collection. It takes in a request and collection_id, then gets the collection by its id. Then it checks if there is anything in new_name, if so it changes the name of that specific collection and saves it. If not, an error message will be displayed.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • request – Get the data from the form

  • collection_id – Get the collection from the database

Returns:

The redirect to the edit_collection view

template_name = 'cards/edit_collection.html'¶
cards.views.main.main(request)¶

The main function is the main page of the site. It displays a list of all cards in the database, and allows you to add new ones.

Parameters:

request – Get the request object

Returns:

The main page

Card’s services¶

class cards.services.abstract_class.MessageMixin¶

MixinClass to add template pass for messages.

message_template = 'cards/message.html'¶
class cards.services.cards_services.CardsServices¶
static generate_data(english_word, russian_word, word_usage)¶

The generate_data function takes in three arguments: english_word, russian_word, and word_usage. If the user does not provide an English word or a Russian word, the function will use Google Translate to translate the provided language into the other language. If no usage is provided by the user, then it will be generated using the fact generator function.

Parameters:

  • english_word – Pass the english word to the function

  • russian_word – Pass the russian word to the function

  • word_usage – Pass a fact about the word to the function

Returns:

A tuple of three values

classmethod get_card_from_collection(english=None, russian=None, card_id=None)¶

The get_card_from_collection function takes in a string of either an English word or Russian word, and returns the corresponding card object from the database. If no such card exists, it raises a ValueError.

Parameters:

  • cls – Specify the model class that is being queried

  • english – Get the card from the database using its english word

  • russian – Get the card from the database

  • card_id – Get a card by its id

Returns:

A card from the database

classmethod get_information_from_forms(form)¶

The get_information_from_forms function is a helper function that returns the information from the form. It takes in one argument, which is a form object. It then returns four attributes: english_word, russian_word, word_usage and collection.

Parameters:

  • cls – Get the class of the object

  • form – Get the data from the form

Returns:

The following:

classmethod get_new_card(form)¶

The get_new_card function takes a form and returns a message.

Parameters:

  • cls – Refer to the class itself

  • form – Get the information from the form

Returns:

A dictionary with a message

class cards.services.collections_services.CollectionServices¶
static get_all_cards(collection)¶

The get_all_cards function takes a collection as an argument and returns all of the cards in that collection.

Parameters:

collection – Get all of the cards in that collection

Returns:

A list of all the cards in a collection

static get_collection_by_id(collection_id)¶

The get_collection_by_id function takes in a collection_id and returns the CardsCollections object with that id.

Parameters:

collection_id – Find the collection in the database

Returns:

A collection object

static get_collections_by_owner(owner_id)¶

The get_collections_by_owner function returns a list of all collections owned by the user with the given owner_id.

Parameters:

owner_id – Filter the collections by owner

Returns:

A list of collections that belong to the owner with the given id

cards.services.fact_generator.fact_generator(prompt)¶

The fact_generator function takes a prompt as an argument and returns a fact about China. The function uses the OpenAI API to generate text using the &quot;text-davinci-003&quot; model, which is trained on Wikipedia articles. The function then returns the first choice of generated text from OpenAI’s API.

Parameters:

prompt – Pass in a word that the model will use to generate a fact about china

Returns:

A string

cards.services.translator.translator(text, from_l, to_l)¶

The translator function takes in a string of text, the language it is currently written in, and the language to translate it into. It then uses OpenAI’s API to generate a translation of that text. The function returns this translated text.

Parameters:

  • text – Pass the text to be translated

  • from_l – Specify the language that the text is currently in

  • to_l – Specify the language to translate into

Returns:

A string
